dict.string: Allow booting with a MacPro4,1 or MacPro5,1 SMBIOS definition without ECC memory
Enable TRIM for non-Apple SSD (from config-sample)
Fresco FL1009 USB 3.0 Device ID Patch by bu11etpr00f
Disable USB Port Limit 10.13.4+ by PMHeart & FredWst
AppleAHCIPort patch to fix internal disks displayed as external (Orange Icon) by Slice (from config-sample)

array.string: Recommended Setting for Sandy/Ivy Bridge:
Default:
AsusAICPUPM key was renamed to AppleIntelCPUPM.
Some vendors, like ASUS, restrict the use of MSR register 0xE2 in their power
management module to ReadOnly. On Sandy/Ivy Bridge systems the kext
AppleIntelCpuPowerManagement will try to write to this register and cause a
kernel panic. This patch will eliminate the kext's write operations.
Recommended Setting:
Default:
macOS has compatibility issues with a BIOS CMOS resulting in its reset on each
wake after sleep and reboot, which is noticeable in a loss of BIOS settings. Mostly
Gigabyte motherboards are affected. Usually it can be solved by patching
Device(RTC) in the DSDT.
If this does not help, the kext itself can be patched, which is done here.
Optional Setting for AMD Video Cards:
See #KernelAndKextPatches-EXAMPLES
This method works for systems using Mac OS X 10.7 or newer.
For a fully working AMD Video Card injecting properties into the registry is not
enough. Additionally a modification of the connectors in the according controller
binary file is necessary.
More info in the post of bcc9 on insanelymac.
http://www.insanelymac.com/forum/topic/249642-editing-custom-personalities-for-ati-radeon-hd45xxx/
Optional Setting for AMD Video Cards:
See #KernelAndKextPatches-EXAMPLES
For Description See ATIConnectorsController
Optional Setting for AMD Video Cards:
See #KernelAndKextPatches-EXAMPLES
For Description See ATIConnectorsController
Optional Setting:
See #KernelAndKextPatches-EXAMPLES
NO DESCRIPTION ON WIKI (from config-sample.plist)
Recommended Setting:
Default Setting:
Enables detailed output describing the patching process. This prints kernel
patches and kext injection debug messages to the screen, since standard boot log
is already closed. Useful for debugging purposes.
Useful for debugging purposes.
Optional Setting:
Default Setting:
NO DESCRIPTION ON WIKI (from config-sample.plist)
Optional Setting to Replace "KernelCpu":
NOT USED
Fake CPUID is intended to be a replacement for the "KernelCpu" Patch.
It influences the kernel and AppleCPUPowerManagement as well.
If you want to install OSX with an unsupported CPU then you'll need to fake its ID
to avoid kernel panics. Useful if you're trying to install OSX with an Atom CPU, or
10.7.2 with an IvyBridge CPU.
For these cases Clover allows you to set FakeCPUID in config.plist or even through
the GUI, in the Binaries patching menu.
Optional Setting for Unsupported CPU's:
Default Setting:
Eliminates kernel panics related to an Unsupported CPU like Yonah, Atom or
Haswell for old systems. However, the kernel has other algorithms which will not
work correctly when using an unsupported CPU and this patch will not solve all
problems. It is highly unlikely that this will work with a Pentium M, Pentium 4 or
and AMD. The use of a special replacement kernel is advised in such cases.
Optional Setting for Haswell-E:
Default Setting:
Haswell-E setups are currently not supported by the OS X kernel (as of macOS
10.10.2). This patch gets rid of the blocking compatibility checks.
Note: this will NOT enable Power Management or similar features.
Optional Setting:
Default Setting:
NO DESCRIPTION ON WIKI (from config-sample.plist)
Optional Setting for HP Notebooks:
Default Setting:
HP Notebooks have lapic problems, which can be solved by using the boot
parameter cpus=1 or by using this option.
Optional Setting for Haswell:
Default Setting:
Kernel power management patch for Haswell with locked msrs. Works with 10.8.5
and 10.9 kernels.
Haswell CPU's include Xeon v3 (E3 / E5 / E7) and Core iX (Gen4 / Gen5)
Optional Setting:
See #KernelAndKextPatches-EXAMPLES
Force load kexts (and plugins) from booted volume so it can be patched. It also
accepts directories to force load/inject every kext in the folder.
Optional Setting:
See #KernelAndKextPatches-EXAMPLES
Apart from the built-in patches you can create your own ones providing following
data: the binary file name, the data to find and the data to replace with - both in
hexadecimal. The data length must be equal. A smaller replacement data line can
be filled with zeroes.
Side note: The patch is supposed to be done in the cache. If you patch an
Info.plist to allow the loading of a kext, then it is not yet present in the cache.
You will need to reboot twice. First with the key NoCaches to allow FSInject to load
the kext and a second time for the cache to be patched successfully.
Recommended Setting:
NO DESCRIPTION ON WIKI (Since revision r3259)
Recommended Setting:
Since revision r3259
Controls System Integrity Protection (SIP)
Relevant user options for SIP:
0x0 = SIP Enabled (Default)
0x3 = SIP Partially Disabled (Loads unsigned kexts)
0x67 = SIP Disabled completely
Recommended Setting:
UseMacAddr0
This Value is the Platform UUID or Hardware UUID (Universally Unique Identifier)
shown in macOS in System Information under Hardware Overview.
NOTE: This Platform / Hardware UUID, in connection with the System UUID:
(SMBIOS->SmUUID) Value, is needed to enable iMessage functionality.
Twelve hexadecimal digits, often corresponding to the unique MAC Address of
your Ethernet Card. According to several reports this value can also be random.
Since revision 3051 Clover can detect the LAN MAC address of an ethernet
device and use it as ROM.
For UEFI, it will first check the UEFI protocol for LAN information; but for legacy
it will attempt to get it from the hardware instead, and because this procedure is
dangerous, you'll need to enable the functionality by specifying the LAN device
with: UseMacAddr0 or UseMacAddr1
(up to 4 devices are calculated but only 2 will be used).
This group of parameters is used to mask your PC as a Mac. Clover will do this
task automatically based on the given processor, video card and signs of mobility.
However, you may choose differently. Get the MacTracker application, choose a
model you like and find matching values. Clover Configurator can help you with
this task. There is not much to comment here, these values are not for beginners.
If you know them - change them; otherwise leave it. Calculating them is mostly
not possible.
SMBIOS.table3->AssetTag
Example Setting:
Motherboard or Computer Model / SN / Service Tag
This field is never used with real Macs. We can use it for our own purpose.
e.g. in the HWSensors project.
Can be automatically generated by Clover Configurator SMBIOS Selection.
Inject custom memory module tables into SMBIOS if original SPD and SMBIOS
provide incorrect or incomplete information.
Example Setting:
Number of Hardware Channels supported by your Memory Chipset.
Usually 2 for 16-32GB Max; 4 for 64GB Max. See Motherboard Documentation.
Array of INSTALLED Memory Modules. Don't add Entries for EMPTY Slots.
Example Setting:
The Memory Module's Speed in Megahertz.
Example Setting:
PV316G160C9K
The Memory Module's Part Number Identifier.
Example Setting:
The Memory Module's Size in Megabytes.
Example Setting:
The Physical Slot Locate in which the Memory Module is installed. (e.g. 0-7)
Optional Setting (Not Required)
The Memory Module's Serial Number.
Example Setting:
DDR3
The Memory Module's Type.
Example Setting:
Patriot
The Memory Module's Manufacturer Name.
Example Setting:
Total count of memory slots in your system. Max 24 (for now).
Can be automatically generated by Clover Configurator SMBIOS Selection.
Example Setting (DO NOT USE IN YOUR CONFIG):
PREREQUISITE: SystemParameters->InjectSystemID MUST be defined, and enabled,
for this Key to function correctly.
The purpose of these two Keys are to provide an way for Users to specify, or continue
using thier existing (Chameleon) System UUID.
Use uuidgen in Terminal to generate a new random UUID to use for this Value, or
use your existing (Chamelon) System UUID.
This is the System UUID (Universally Unique Identifier), which is written into the
SMBIOS table. This Value found in registry at IODeviceTree:/efi/platform>system-id.
***This Value IS NOT the Hardware UUID displayed in macOS System Information***
NOTE: This System UUID, in connection with the Platform / Hardware UUID:
(RtVariables->ROM) Value, is needed to enable iMessage functionality.
Default Setting:
Used to give priority to memory descriptor values found in SMBIOS or SPD.
Change if your memory is described incorrectly in macOS System Information.
SMBIOS.table1->ProductName
Example Setting:
MacPro6,1
Setting this value will enable Clover to automatically generate dependent
parameters related to the model specified, so you can leave them out.
NOTE: Custom values will be preferred over generated ones.
Generated Values: BiosReleaseDate, BiosVendor, BiosVersion, Board-ID,
BoardManufacturer, BoardType, BoardVersion, ChassisManufacturer, ChassisType,
Family, FirmwareFeatures, FirmwareFeaturesMask, LocationInChassis,
Manufacturer, PlatformFeature, Version
Clover has built-in definitions for following models:
MacBook1,1 MacBook2,1 MacBook4,1 MacBook5,1 MacBook5,2
MacBook6,1 MacBook7,1 MacBook8,1 MacBook9,1 MacBook10,1

SMBIOS.table3->Type
Example Setting for MacPro6,1:
Used as an indirect indication for platform mobility. Clover will use a value
according to the set Mac model, like it is used in real Macs. The effect, except
mobility settings, is unclear.

Example Setting for MacPro6,1:
Recommended Setting:
Yes
Default Setting:
Global Policy. This Key regulates Kext Injection.
Yes or <true/> - Always inject kexts from /EFI/CLOVER/kexts/
No or <false/> - Never inject kexts
Detect - Kexts from /EFI/CLOVER/kexts/ will be injected only if FakeSMC is not
present in the kernelcache.
Any conflicting Value defined in any "Custom Entries" will override this Setting.
Recommended Setting:
Default Setting:
NOTE: This Key MUST be defined, and enabled, in order to use the Key:
SMBIOS->SmUUID.
The purpose of these two Keys are to provide an way for Users to specify, or continue
using thier existing (Chameleon) System UUID.
Use uuidgen in Terminal to generate a new random UUID to use for the
SMBIOS->SmUUID Value, or use your existing (Chamelon) System UUID.
This is the System UUID (Universally Unique Identifier), which is written into the
SMBIOS table. This Value found in registry at IODeviceTree:/efi/platform>system-id.
***This Value IS NOT the Hardware UUID displayed in macOS System Information***
NOTE: This System UUID, in connection with the Platform / Hardware UUID:
(RtVariables->ROM) Value, is needed to enable iMessage functionality.
Recommended Setting:
Default Setting:
Global Policy. If enabled, this Key will force the Cache to be skipped during each
boot. Any conflicting Value defined in any "Custom Entries" will override this Setting.
Recommended Setting for NVIDIA:
Default Setting:
Global Policy. If enabled, this Key will enable macOS >= 10.12 to load and use
NVIDIA's WebDriver Ketxts.
